Use the resources below to report cyber incidents to the appropriate authorities. If you or someone else is in immediate danger, please call 911 or local police.

content.brief: Cyber.gov is a collection of cybersecurity best practices and other resources to help you safely and responsibly navigate in an increasingly connected world
content.micro: Learn more about Cyber.gov, including our privacy policy and contact information
Cyber.gov serves as a central collection of cybersecurity tips, best practices, and other resources that inform the public on how to protect themselves from cybersecurity threats.

Should you identify a potential error on this website, including failure to include a significant resource relating to the responsibilities and practices for Federal agencies, or if you have encountered an accessibility problem, please email us at OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov. Although we are interested in your feedback and suggestions, please be aware that we may not be able to respond to all email inquiries.

If you choose to provide feedback or to report an issue with accessibility and you send us your personally identifiable information via email at OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov, we will only use that information to respond to your message.

Protecting the privacy and security of individuals’ personal information is very important to us. We will not obtain personally identifying information about you when you visit our site unless you choose to provide that information by contacting us. However, the website may collect a limited amount of information about your visit for the purposes of website analytics and customization. Please read this notice to understand what we do with the limited amount of information about your visit that we may collect.

For site security purposes and to ensure that this service remains available to all users, this Government computer system employs software programs to monitor network traffic to identify unauthorized attempts to upload or change information, or otherwise cause damage. Unauthorized attempts to upload information or change information on this service are strictly prohibited and may be punishable under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986 and the National Information Infrastructure Protection Act.

content.brief: Key Federal agency cybersecurity performance metrics, in support of a secure and transparent government
content.micro: Explore performance by Federal agencies on key cybersecurity metrics

Established by the Government Performance and Results Modernization Act (GPRA) of 2010, the Cross-Agency Priority (CAP) Goals aim to accelerate progress on a limited number of Presidential priority areas where implementation requires active collaboration between multiple agencies. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Cyber and National Security Unit, in partnership with the National Security Council (NSC), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and Department of Defense (DoD), drives implementation of the cybersecurity CAP Goal amongst the federal agencies. This CAP Goal has a mission statement of, “Improve cybersecurity performance through ongoing awareness of information security, vulnerabilities, and threats impacting the operating information environment, ensuring that only authorized users have access to resources and information; and the implementation of technologies and processes that reduce the risk of malware.”

In accordance with the Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014 (FISMA), the annual report provides Congress and the public information on agency progress towards meeting cybersecurity performance goals and identifies areas in need of improvement. This report also provides information on Federal cybersecurity incidents, ongoing efforts to mitigate and prevent future incidents, and agencies’ progress in implementing cybersecurity policies and programs to protect their systems, networks, and data.

content.brief: Resources for current and aspiring cybersecurity professionals interested in joining the Federal cybersecurity workforce
content.extended: Read about our strategy to harden the Federal cybersecurity workforce, and discover opportunities for Federal service.
content.micro: Learn how you can help through Federal cybersecurity career opportunities
Resources that can be used to find cybersecurity job opportunities in the Federal Government.

On July 12, 2016, the White House released the first-ever Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy, which details government-wide actions to identify, expand, recruit, develop, retain and sustain a capable and competent workforce to address complex and ever-evolving cyber threats.

content.brief: A suggested reading list to help acquaint you with the Federal cybersecurity policy environment
content.micro: An introduction to the policies and standards of the Federal cybersecurity landscape

Statute or laws as passed by the United States Congress as they relate to requirements placed on Federal agencies. Please note that this list should serve as a starting point, and should not be considered exhaustive.

Legally binding orders issued by the President to direct Federal agencies and officials in their execution of congressionally established laws or policies. Please note that this list should serve as a starting point, and should not be considered exhaustive.

content.brief: Information about the Chief Information Security Officers (CISO) Council, a body of executives who are responsible for ensuring the security of Federal information systems

sections.title: About the Chief Information Security Officers Council

content.micro: The Chief Information Security Officers (CISO) Council is the principal inter-agency forum uniting agencies’ efforts to strengthen the cybersecurity posture of the United States Government.

content.brief:
Promote an open and transparent government that protects the People’s information while preserving privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties.

- Greg J. Touhill
United States Chief Information Security Officer
content.micro: Learn more about our guiding principles for protecting Federal information systems
The cybersecurity strategy of the United States Chief Information Security Officer is executed along five lines of effort.

Taking bold actions to protect Americans in today’s digital world. 

From buying products to running businesses to finding directions to communicating with the people we love, an online world has fundamentally reshaped our daily lives.  But just as the continually evolving digital age presents boundless opportunities for our economy, our businesses, and our people, it also presents a new generation of threats that we must adapt to meet.  Criminals, terrorists, and countries who wish to do us harm have all realized that attacking us online is often easier than attacking us in person.  As more and more sensitive data is stored online, the consequences of those attacks grow more significant each year.  

Meeting these new threats is necessary and within our grasp.  But it requires a bold reassessment of the way we approach security in the digital age.  If we’re going to be connected, we need to be protected.  We need to join together—Government, businesses, and individuals—to sustain the spirit that has always made America great. 

The Cybersecurity National Action Plan (CNAP) is the capstone of more than seven years of determined effort, building upon lessons learned from cybersecurity trends, threats, and intrusions.  This plan directs the Federal Government to take bold action and fosters the conditions required for long-term improvements in our approach to cybersecurity across the Federal Government, the private sector, and our personal lives.

content.brief: A collection of tips that you can follow to help you or your organization safely and responsibly navigate in an increasingly connected world
content.extended: Discover easy steps you can take to improve your cybersecurity
content.micro: Easy steps you can take to reduce your vulnerability to cybersecurity threats
There is no infallible way to guarantee your safety on the internet, but these tips can prevent you from being an easy target for hackers.
In addition to applying the principles from the tips for home users, these steps can be used to help secure your organization.
For more tips on protecting yourself or your organization, see the resources below.
